text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum for you today
we're tackling the vinaigrette and what
is a vinaigrette we'll simply put it's
an emulsion of an acid within a fat so
acid droplets suspended in fat and today
I'm going to show you the trick in
making sure you keep your emulsion
there's one ingredient that will really
help to do this I have a small bowl here
I'm going to add our secret ingredient
and that is mustard mustard is a great
emulsifier it helps to keep your
vinaigrette from separating other items
that would be just as good as an
emulsifier would be an egg yolk if
you're willing and also roasted garlic
is also a great emulsifier so I have 2
tablespoons of Dijon mustard you could
use a whole grain mustard you could use
a flavored mustard if you'd like and
what's so great about using mustard as
an emulsifier it has the spicy zippy
flavor that really adds a lot of punch
to your vinaigrette now I'm going to add
the acid and typically with a
vinaigrette the ratio of acid to oil is
one part acid to three parts oil I
prefer using a smaller quantity of oil
so that the vinaigrette has more of a
tangy zip enos to it that was six
tablespoons of red wine vinegar you
could use white wine vinegar you could
do sherry vinegar any vinegar that you
have in your pantry is perfectly
acceptable here some vinegars have more
acidity than others like white wine
vinegar has about 7% acidity red wine
vinegar is a little bit less at about 6%
so now I'm adding a hefty pinch of salt
so about a teaspoon of salt for this
ratio of oil and vinegar and a half a
teaspoon of pepper and this might seem
like a lot of salt and pepper to you but
think about it this dressing is going to
flavor all of those greens so you have
to really season it liberally vinegar
mustard salt and pepper and I'm going to
whisk this together until it's combined
what will happen here is the salt will
dissolve into the vinegar you're going
to break up the mustard and incorporate
it into the vinegar and we're ready now
for our oil and I'm using about 3/4 of a
cup of olive oil here so that's about
two-to-one ratio so 6 tablespoons of
acid
and 3/4 of a cup or about 12 tablespoons
of olive oil what you want to do to
create an emulsion is slowly drizzle in
your oil if you do it too quickly you're
going to break the emulsion but there's
so much mustard in here that you're
really set up for success so I'm gonna
slowly drizzle this in now you could
also use a combination of olive oil and
a lighter oil like a safflower oil or a
grape seed oil something that has a
little less flavor but I really love the
flavor of olive oil so I tend to make my
vinaigrette with just the olive oil I'm
using vinegar here today but you could
also use citrus juice that's really
great adds wonderful flavor if you
wanted to really give your vinaigrette
some pizazz you could add some minced
shallot or you could add a little bit of
citrus zest or some herbs it really does
kind of help to amp up the flavor and
make a better salad dressing you could
also do this easily in the jar of a
blender that really works well and
you'll get a great emulsion or you could
shake it in jar and that works as well
too so that's the last of the oil here
you can see that the dressing hasn't
separated it all it's nice and thick and
one consistency and now what I'm gonna
do is I'm going to give it a taste and
it's very important here that you
actually taste it with what you're going
to eat it with so I'm gonna make a
simple salad today so I'm going to use
the lettuce to try it if you dip your
finger and you give it a taste you're
not gonna get the true experience this
is good needs a little bit of salt and a
little bit more pepper and now I'm ready
to dress the salad I have just simple
greens here but it's great about a
vinaigrette is it so versatile you can
dress up some roasted vegetables or
grilled vegetables you can do a simple
salad like this or you can mix it with
some grains and pasta and create some
really unique offerings so I have about
of 1/2 of a head of crunchy greens here
and that's like a romaine or a bib
lettuce and to this I'm going to add the
vinaigrette and not all of it dress it
lightly to start around the side of the
bowl remember this is a high acid
vinaigrette a little goes a long way you
won't end up with a soggy oversaturated
salad because
there is so much flavor in this
vinaigrette and then take some tongs and
gently fold the lettuce leaves into the
vinaigrette you want to make sure when
you're dressing a salad that you do it
right before serving because the oil in
the vinegar will saturate the lettuce
leaves and it will start to wilt the
salad and you can't really do that in
advance otherwise you're going to end up
with a soggy mess so this looks great
I'm just going to place it on a nice
platter and there you have it a very
simple way to make a delicious flavorful
emulsified vinaigrette enjoy
